Award.AwardTitle: Computational Design of Ultraselective Desalination Membranes using Molecular Simulations and Path Sampling Techniques

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Semipermeable membranes selectively impede the passage of undesirable molecules and ions in a fluid, while allowing the desirable molecules to pass through the membrane. This type of technology is key to many applications as well as natural processes. For instance, membranes that are only water permeable and reject most other ions and molecules are used in water desalination. Similarly, biological cells feature membranes capable of modulating the passage of small molecules and ions into and out of the cell. On a molecular level, a membraneâ€™s selectivity is dictated by its nanostructure, i.e., the geometry, topology, and chemistry of its constituent nanopores. However, there is much yet to learn about how a membrane's structure is fundamentally related to its selectivity for certain ions and molecules. On one hand, existing experimental techniques lack the necessary spatiotemporal resolution to characterize membrane structure and to probe isolated solute (the molecule or ion) passage events. On the other hand, conventional molecular simulation techniques can provide information about events at the correct length-scale, but the average time it takes to observe an undesirable solute passing through a highly selective membrane is beyond the reach of standard molecular simulation methods. These factors limit our ability to understand important natural processes (such as biological membrane transport and solute transport in porous media) and hamper efforts to rationally design ultraselective membranes for desalination and gas and chemical separation applications.

The goal of this proposal is to conduct a systematic investigation of the structure-selectivity relationship in nanoporous membranes using molecular dynamics simulations and advanced path sampling techniques. The investigator recently developed a novel path sampling algorithm that makes it possible to accurately and efficiently estimate arbitrarily long solute transport timescales under operationally realistic conditions. The algorithm is also capable of reconstructing an accurate and statistically representative picture of the solute transport mechanism. This approach will be used to probe the kinetics and molecular mechanisms of pressure-driven solute transport through nanoporous membranes with well-defined geometries and chemistries. The project focuses on membranes used in desalination applications, but the developed computational tools can be universally applied to other membrane-based separation processes. The research plan sets out first to develop new computational tools and methods for studying solute transport through membranes. Subsequently, the investigator will conduct a set of hypothesis-based calculations that address important fundamental questions about the structure-selectivity relationship in membranes and hindered transport under nanoscale confinement. To this end, both simple model carbon-based membranes with well-defined structures and chemistries and synthetic membranes such as zeolites and metal-organic frameworks will be examined. Collaboration with experimental groups at Yale complements the modeling efforts, as membranes with well-defined structures will be synthesized and performance in membrane-based desalination will be assessed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award aimed to leverage molecular dynamics simulations and advanced path sampling techniques to investigate how the structure of nanoporous membranes influences their selectivity towards various molecules, with a focus on membranes used in water desalination. Ideally, desalination membranes are desired to allow water molecules to traverse while mostly rejecting salts and other small molecules. In order to systematically address this question, one needs the ability to accurately estimate transport timescales for ions and molecules rejected by selective membranes, which is challenging to achieve by conventional molecular simulations. In a work published in 2020 (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matt.2019.12.022), we developed a framework based on forward flux sampling to address this challenge and to accurately and efficiently estimate solute translocation timescales, irrespective of their magnitude. This methodology made it possible to systematically probe the question of structure-selectivity relationship in membranes, and to examine the fundamental laws of transport at the nanoscale. The aforementioned paper inspired the key ideas of this award, which has already resulted in three major achievements, two in the realm of developing new computational tools for studying nanoscale transport, and one in probing the physics of hindered ion transport through nanopores:

Major Achievements:

1.  Ideal conductor/dielectric model (ICDM): A physics-based approach to rectify finite-size artifacts in ion transport simulations: Due to constraints in computational power and memory, modern atomistic molecular simulations are conducted within nanoscale simulation boxes comprised of 104-106 molecules. In order to avoid interfacial artifacts, such simulations typically employ periodic boundary conditions, which can, in turn, result in inaccurate estimates of physical properties. Such systematic biases are usually negligible for simple thermodynamic and structural properties, but can be substantial when it comes to rates and free energy barriers of activated phenomena and rare events. In this project, we demonstrated that finite size artifacts can be massive in ion transport simulations wherein an ion leaves a reservoir, potentially resulting in discrepancies that are several orders of magnitude large. We successfully developed the physics-based ICDM model to rectify such artifacts that emanate from the periodic replicates of the image charges induced within the reservoir(s) upon the translocation of the ion of interest. What is remarkable about the ICDM model is that it corrects for such artifacts "on-the-spot", i.e., using the information obtained from a single finite-size simulation to predict translocation barriers and rates in the thermodynamic limit. In addition to assisting us in studying desalination membranes, the ICDM model can be universally applied to study ion transport simulations for other applications.

2- Develop new kernel-based estimators for computing position-dependent anisotropic diffusivity tensors from molecular dynamics trajectories: Diffusivity is a measure of how fast a molecules can move within a sea of other molecules, and is usually a scalar (i.e., isotropic) property in bulk liquids. Under confinement, however, it becomes both anisotropic and position-dependent, features that are particularly critical to proper understanding of the behavior of fluids in nanopores. As part of this award, we derived and validated a new class of kernel-based estimators to compute anisotropic diffusivity profiles from MD trajectories. This methodology is not only useful in probing spatial dynamical heterogeneities in nanoporous desalination membranes, but can be broadly applied to simulations of confined fluids in general. 

3- Role of pore proximity on selectivty and permeability: in our first attempt to employ these techniques to probe the structure-selectivity relationship in desalination membranes, we demonstrated that nanopores with interiors decorated with dipoles tend to exhibit strong correlations when placed in nano-proximity of one another. These correlations adversely impact membrane selectivity by slowing down the transport of water (henceforth decreasing per-pore water flux) and counter-ions, while accelerating the transport of co-ions. These correlations surpass the predictions of classical theories, such as the access resistance model, substantially. We also develop a phenomenological model that enables us to screen nanoporous membranes for the extent of such correlations, and to design pore arrangements that exert minimal correlations. Beyond desalination, these observations can have strong implications for designing membranes for ion separation membranes for ion separation, as well as in studies of biological channel proteins.

These achievements significantly advance our understanding of nanoscale transport physics and pave the way for designing more efficient and selective nanoporous membranes for various applications.
